Name: The Birth of Tragedy: Out of the Spirit of Music (Penguin Classics)
Author: Friedrich Nietzsche

Reviews.Text: If you have not read this I must ask why.  Then I must ask you to ask yourself why. Anything by Nietzche is not just interesting and a learning experience, it is hillarious as well.  despite the label of being a nihlist, given by people who never read him or disagree with him, Nietzche has a profound insight to life that is actually quite joyous-not just in this work but in general.  I suggest every book he has, mind you I am biased as I was a philosophy major and had to read him anyway, bvut I had read him befor that too. It's worth it to buy this alone or better yet buy a collected works that includes his other work as well.
read it for ethics class long ago and I loved it so much

Reviews.Header: great book read it 40 years ago and again now..
Reviews.Text: a classic.. his writings on intellect awareness and our view of ourselves is excellent writing..

Reviews.Header: These thoughts must be read by all.
Reviews.Text: One of the greatest, if not the greatest philosopher tempts us to examine our essence-human all too human. This is beyond literature, an experience for the self. Definitively, this is a book no one should neglect to read, even if once, this is a philosopher's philosopher. To the layman, essential and thought-provoking, dangerously liberating.
Classic! Everyone should be reading this.

We are in 1871, have a good look around. There are people defending that life should be "serious"; no novels, no theater, no music… But here comes Nietzsche with a counterargument! He warms up assuming that you know a great deal about Greek tragedy. And goes around asking: Why humans need art? Well, ordinary lives are full of drama but the variation between tragedy and triumph is not in the same magnitude as in mythology. In his own words: "Tragedy forces us to look at the terrors of individual existence, yet we are not to be petrified with fear".  And the pleasant side is a supreme gratification from nature. Thus art sets the bounds for WONDER, so humans are set for ACTION. Once in motion, humans are no longer artists but a work of art.
Great reading
excellent

Reviews.Header: One of the Must Reads in the Topic of Philosophy
Reviews.Text: This is one of the foundations that anyone interested in Philosophy will read at some point.  Nietzshe is one of the key authors in this area and will form the core of most discussions in morality.
arguably the finest thinker of our time, and this work is opening my mind to many new ideas.

Reviews.Header: Spectacular book, if at times a bit cryptic (it is Nietzsche, after all)
Reviews.Text: It is the first time that I've read one of Nietzsche's books, and I have to say that it is staggering. I will not claim I understood it all. It would take much more than casual reading for that, but even so, I cannot recommend it enough.
What can I say
I found it a wonderfully interesting read.  It is dense, so prior knowledge of Western intellectual history is very helpful.
outstanding review of Greek tragedy.  eminating from the human condition itself / i wish that it might have included psychological analysis of human tragedy from which Greek tragedy theater evolved.

Reviews.Header: Same Old Tragedy. But to be able to project beyond cultural boundaries the reaches of Greek culture is the gift of Nietzche. I like it that I makes me think and imagine. We probably still live with mythical gods. We just call them by a different name.
Reviews.Text: Same Old Tragedy. To be able to project beyond cultural boundaries the reaches of Greek culture is the gift of Nietzche. He could have titled it The Birth of Pleasure and it would stick. I like it that it makes me think and imagine. We probably still live with mythical gods. We just call them by a different name.
this is another book needed in your Nietzsche collection. I read this book and was blown away, it's a must have.
Nietzsche was amazing
Ty
Good

Nietzsche was brilliantly crazy or crazy brilliant, perhaps it was both.  Not an obvious genius, but his wisdom is counter-intuitive and worthy of reflection.  He was perhaps the most brilliant philosopher of his time, certainly not the most conventional--but arguably the most sagacious about many matters.  It is a shame that he descended into madness. He is not to be read quickly, because in so doing you will miss the point.  Worth reading and reflecting on, particularly if you study philosophy seriously.
It was free on kindle. Can't go wrong with that.
Good info for the paper on the problem of evil that I was writing.
Not easy to read, but well worth it.

I think the poor guy needed a hug. Maybe a long hug? Like a really long hug. Someone to say “I love you”...
not a bad read

Reviews.Header: Interesting but outdated, always included old-school "99% fact-free" factual philological reasoning!
Reviews.Text: Truly there is no school like the old school. Dense and superficially articulate, Nietzsche's subtext bubbles with barely-suppressed rage at theocratic institutions which still exert control over society. If you want to read a book which absolutely blasts the "Church" element of the ancient institutions of Church and State which form the two main pillars over the marketplace of society's boulevard, start here.
This book has been an immense help, having read it along side the Kaufman translation. But who translated THIS version? To have any kind of legitimacy as a reference, the translator must be known!
it is too difficult to follow, I guess I am not a genius..
the ebook translation is not good....Big nietzsche fan tho
The description on this product isn't accurate as it's translated by William A Haussmann and not Walter Kaufmann, strange mistake.

Drivel. Aphorisms that have no connection to anything. Just one person's opinion. Only at the very end as he began to sound like a philosopher. But there seems to be no desire to make his case. Looks like I need to read an interpretation of all of his works to get an idea of why he is so respected as a philosopher.

Reviews.Header: I know that Nietzche is a famous philosopher, but ...
Reviews.Text: I know that Nietzche is a famous philosopher, but I just couldn't get into it. In the opening chapter, even in translation, I seemed to hear a sneering tone, which seemed to me typical of German writers of his time. I was able to put the book down.

I read about a third of this little pamphlet before I lost interest.  His gibes at his academic colleagues didn't carry much sting, since I didn't know to whom he referred.  I guess that he would have been a good writer of advertising copy, but he seemed a bit out of his depth writing about absolutes like good and evil, or maybe that was his correct level, trying to deal with concepts so abstract that they have very little meaning.  I like a good novel, I enjoy math, I practice chemistry in various forms, but these words had no attraction for me beyond some curiosity about what he was famous for.

Reviews.Header: eBook is not the Kaufmann translation
Reviews.Text: The eBook and the version of the paperback showing the two eyes in a frame are not the Kaufmann translation. This translation is OK, but you should know that the product information is incorrect.
This ebook is illegible. Someone just did an OCR scan of an existing translation, without fixing any of the problems. About once a sentence, two or more words are crammed together likethis.

Reviews.Header: The Kindle edition is NOT the Walter Kaufmann translation.
Reviews.Text: This is NOT the Walter Kaufmann translation as implied by being linked to the Kaufmann paperback edition.

The preview audiobook is the professional Audible narration, but after you buy the book you will find the audiobook is the free LibriVox amateur version, full of mispronunciations and awkward pauses.
